Key Arguments: Concerns about a single body being the sole arbiter of correct and incorrect information.
Potential for interference with dissenting opinions under the guise of safety, leading to a reduction in free speech.
Fear that media platforms will self-censor to avoid penalties, stifling free speech.
Exclusion of government and major media sources from the Bill, raising concerns about government influence.
Broad definition of 'harm' could lead to censorship of controversial opinions.
Belief that the Bill will tip the balance towards state censorship over individual judgment.
Main Themes: Broad definitions leading to potential overreach
Notable Quotes: There is potential for interference with the publication of dissenting opinions under the guise of 'keeping us safe' which would be effectively a winding back of free speech.
The exclusion of Government and potentially major media sources from the new Bill is also of concern to me.
This introduces the spectre of censorship of opinion (even if it has merit) on the basis that it does not agree with broader public or (particularly) Government policy.
